title: When was the oldest Christian hymn written and who wrote it? - Quora

response.answer_text: It depends exactly what you mean by a ‘hymn’, which simply means as song of praise. As has been said, the psalms are the oldest hymns and are still in vigorous use as such. Some scholars see fragments of hymns buried in some of the New Testament epistles. One ancient hymn from early Christian times is ‘phos hilarion’ - ‘hail gladdening light’, an anonymous verse dating from maybe 290AD. ‘Modern’ hymns - verses of fixed metre with a repeated tune - seem to date from the time of St Ambrose (340-397AD). Most mainline hymn books contain a few hymns claiming Ambrose as their author.

The oldest Christian hymns were the Psalms. We don’t know exactly who wrote each one, but David is considered the author of many. This is not surprising, since the earliest Christians were all Jews (as was Jesus). In the Catholic Church, we still sing the Psalms every Sunday if there is sufficient musical accompaniment (otherwise, the Psalms are read rather than sung).
We have 6 hymns in our hymnbook written by Bernard of Clairvaux, who lived 1090–1153. Also 4 hymns by Ambrose of Milan, who lived 340–97. One of Abrose’s hymns is “Savior of the Nations, Come.”
